Indeed.
You know, there's, I'd like to say, a challenging

So it's very much at the outset, I do want to

I love that definition of being set apart,

Well, it's interesting. You know, the first point to
make in this is that when people bring a spiritual,
a religious lens to psychotherapy, even if they're provided with secular treatment,
that treatment has spiritual meaning. And we've

I think it happens for two reasons. The one is
that if you have a spiritual message, even if
you're speaking to someone who's not religious,
who's not spiritual, who's secular, and they're
providing you with messages, you're going to
filter it through your lens of spirituality.
The other thing is when people have a reduction
in their symptoms and they are having an improved
mood, it's easier for them to access that
which they value and that which they believe.
Now, conversely, when you provide people with spiritual psychotherapy,
it's less important if they're religious or
spiritual, and it's more important if they want

shows something interesting, which is that it's

if you provide spiritual care to people who

And if you typecast them based on their religious

So these are conundrums and confounds, in fact,
that actually make it quite difficult to assess

a lot of success in providing spiritual care,

Over 6,000, 7,000 patients at this point have

And patients with all sorts of diagnoses, from

patients receiving it, which is pretty amazing
in the last several years. And patients with

treatments are tolerated well. There's a high

um, and sometimes help us to maintain them, even though they might be challenging.

to prescribe spirituality, and I, like I said,
I agree with you, it's very personal. At the

And do you have a remedy for that? Yeah, good
